subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... I realize that RP has NORTH = FORCE = THOUGHT = CURE, but I was not trying to show how RP works, but to map the QS letters to a (hypothetical) dialect that
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> - Received Pronunciation English pronounces "north" and "awe" the same
> thus "north" should be under the letter Awe #33 not #34
> - RP pronounces "force" as "awe" and thus "force" needs to be under
> the letter Awe #33 not #34

I realize that RP has NORTH = FORCE = THOUGHT = CURE, but I was not trying
to show how RP works, but to map the QS letters to a (hypothetical)
dialect that makes the maximal number of distinctions that QS can
represent.

(The other RP merger is PALM = BATH = START.)

> - RP pronounces "cure" and "foot" with the same vowel. So "cure" is
> #39 Foot+Roe in that accent.

That's a very conservative, old-fashioned RP, probably closer to Read's
time than ours. Current RP speakers merge CURE with FORCE and the
others, as shown above.

> - in RP, "near" and "it" use the same vowel thus "near" uses #26 It +
> Roe not #27

Again, I wasn't doing RP; I was doing an abstraction. Both RP and
most varieties of American changed historic /ir/ to /Ir/ (or /i@/
in non-rhotic accents). Read isn't very definite about this.

--
John Cowan <cowan@...>
http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
.e'osai ko sarji la lojban.
